Award.AwardTitle: Local Algorithms for Random Networks: Power, Limitations and Applications

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
The research objective of this award is to develop systematic understanding of the performance and limitations of local algorithms for combinatorial optimization problems on random networks. The scale of modern technological, communication and social networks renders many computational tools and concepts too impractical to meet the contemporary computational speeds. In light of this challenge, the research on network computational models has recently focused on local algorithms paradigm. One of the most common generative models for real life networks is the random graph model. Thus the research focuses on the performance and limitations of local algorithms for random graphs. A particular focus is on studying the so-called solution space geometry of combinatorial problems on random graphs and its implications for the design and analysis of local algorithms. It is now known that certain optimization problems undergo a phase transition property, dubbed shattering, described as splitting of the space of feasible solutions into many disconnected components. Many attempts to construct algorithms which perform beyond this phase transition point did not succeed. Thus the shattering property is conjectured to be the main "culprit" for the non-existence of local algorithms beyond the phase transition point. A recent work of the PI establishes the non-existence of local algorithms for some optimization problems beyond this phase transition point, thus establishing for the first time the direct link between the shattering phase transition property and the performance of algorithms. The research focuses on the systematic study of this fascinating link between the phase transition property and the design of algorithms.

If successful, the results of this research will provide a deep connection between the performance and algorithmic complexity of local algorithms and structural properties of random networks. The research agenda is truly interdisciplinary, lying at the crossroads of several fields. The activities draw on tools from a variety of disciplines, including the theory of algorithms, combinatorics and graph theory, applied probability and statistical physics, thus bringing together ideas from a diverse set of communities. The results of this research will be disseminated in top journals and conferences in the respective fields. Research seminars will be conducted to introduce students to the topic of algorithms and computations on networks.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The results of this research significantly improved the state of the art understanding on the power and limits of local algorithms in solving optimization problem in random settings, such as random graphs. The work of the PI and his collaborators, which establishes the limits of local algorithm for finding a large independent set of a sparse random graphs, has sparked a significant interest and several follow up papers. It further led to an intriguing  dichotomy observed for a large variety of optimization problem on random inputs:  such problems are either solvable using very simple local type algorithms, or they do not seem to admit  polynomial time algorithms at all. Understanding this dichotomy is now one of the most fundamental open question in the area.


Some of the follow up work conducted within the scope of this proposal includes the following. The PI has established that the so-called Survey Propagation procedure, which is an algorithm motivated by statistical physics considerations, fails to find a satisfying assignment of a random K-SAT problem beyond the regime already covered by trivial algorithms, when the number of message passing rounds is bounded by a constant. A follow up work by a different author established the same result without any restriction on the number of iterations. The key message of the PI's work and the follow up work is that the power of the Survey Propagation algorithm does not significantly exceed the power of already known very simple  algorithms. 


Both of the works described above rely on a fundamental property called Overlap Gap Property which is exhibited by many constraint satisfaction problems and which, as established for the first time by the PI, is a provable obstacle for designing local algorithms. In a follow up work by the PI and his student it is shown that the Overlap Gap Property is a broader phenomena than one observed for randomly generated constraint satisfaction problems. In particular it is shown to be exhibited in the problem of finding the densest submatrix of a matrix with random Gaussian entries. Intriguingly, the onset of the Overlap Gap Property appears to take place at a threshold slightly above the threshold for known algorithms, thus confirming the conjecture that the Overlap Gap Property maybe the obstacle for designing tractable algorithms for a broad class of optimization problems with randomly generated instances.
